;;伊朗自由集会中的示威者在市政厅外抗议支持伊朗妇女并反对 Mahsa (Zhina) Amini 之死2022年10月1日，美国加利福尼亚州洛杉矶。路透社/Bingguan/资料图;
;

;美国和英国周五在;伊朗库尔德妇女马赫萨死亡一周年;阿米尼在伊朗道德警察拘留期间引发了数月的反政府抗议活动，并经常遭到暴力镇压。

;

;22 岁的阿米尼因涉嫌藐视伊斯兰共和国的宪法而被捕，于去年 9 月 16 日去世。强制性着装要求。她的死引发了长达数月的反政府抗议活动，这是多年来反对伊朗当局的最大规模的抗议活动。 ;伊朗安全部队;已部署预计本周末将在她的家乡发生骚乱。

;

;美国、英国以及欧盟已宣布对伊朗实施多轮制裁，理由是死者死后对抗议活动进行了广泛且往往是暴力的镇压阿米尼的。

;

;“马赫萨在伊朗所谓的‘道德警察’的拘留中悲惨而毫无意义地死亡，引发了伊朗各地的示威活动，遭到了难以形容的暴力、大规模逮捕、系统性的互联网中断和伊朗当局的审查。美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯在一份声明中表示，“我们将继续与我们的国际伙伴一起采取适当行动，追究那些压制伊朗人行使人权的人的责任，”他说。说，并补充说，加拿大、澳大利亚和其他合作伙伴本周也实施了制裁。

;

;美国财政部在另一份声明中表示，它对据称与其有关的两打个人和实体实施了制裁阿米尼死后，伊朗对抗议活动进行了“暴力镇压”，包括镇压异议声音和限制互联网。

;

;此次行动针对 29 名个人和团体，其中包括伊斯兰革命卫队的 18 名主要成员（该部门表示，伊朗革命卫队（IRGC）和伊朗执法部队（LEF）以及伊朗监狱组织负责人。他们还针对与伊朗互联网封锁有关的官员和多家媒体。

;

;制裁针对的是 LEF 发言人 Saeed Montazerlmehdi、多名 LEF 和 IRGC 指挥官以及伊朗监狱组织负责人 Gholamali Mohammadi。

;

; Douran Software Technologies 首席执行官 Alireza Abedinejad 以及国家控制的媒体机构 Press TV、Tasnim News Agency 和 Fars News 也在受到制裁之列。

;

;“美国……将继续对这些国家采取集体行动。美国财政部负责恐怖主义和金融情报的副部长布赖恩·纳尔逊在声明中表示：“那些压制伊朗人行使人权的人。”

;

;;英国单独宣布制裁;，针对执行德黑兰强制性头巾法的伊朗高级决策者，包括伊朗文化和伊斯兰部长指导、他的副手、德黑兰市长和伊朗警方发言人。

;罢工的汽车工人聚集在福特车上;(FN); 周五上午在底特律郊区的装配厂表示支持数十年来最雄心勃勃的劳工行动，并解释了导致三工厂的不满罢工。

;

;有史以来第一次同时罢工针对包括通用汽车在内的“底特律三巨头”汽车制造商的罢工;(GM.N) ; 和克莱斯勒母公司 Stellantis ;(STLAM.MI);，提前启动周五，工会和公司未能就新合同达成一致。每家汽车制造商都有;一家工厂关闭;。

;

;周五，在密歇根州韦恩市的福特密歇根装配厂，数十名美国汽车工人联合会 (UAW) 成员在工厂的主入口处设置了纠察线，许多人对过去 15 年来合同和工作规则的变化表示遗憾，尤其是削减了新的规定。 “二级”人员的工资较低，福利也减少。

;

;;UAW 主席肖恩·费恩 (Shawn Fain) 将此次罢工描述为一项社会行动，目的是夺回金融精英夺取的利益，这一信息得到了许多罢工者的响应。

;

;埃里克·穆林斯 (Eric Mullins)，23​​ 岁，他说，他跟随父亲和祖父在福特工作，但作为一名持有二级合同的新员工，他们所创造的生活对他来说是遥不可及的。

;

;三年多后，在福特福特，他退休时没有医疗保险或养老金。

;

;“我什至买不起我开的卡车，”他谈到他的福特 250 皮卡时说道。 “这个国家的富人想要消灭中产阶级。”

;

;周四，首席执行官吉姆·法利警告说，如果福特默许工会要求加薪 40%，结束分级工资制度和恢复固定福利养老金。

;

;UAW 的提议将“让我们破产”，他说。

;

;但 UAW 主席 Fain 表示，福特如果减少股票回购和股东股息，本可以为工人提供更好的工资和福利。福特报告称，到 2022 年将向投资者返还 25 亿美元。

;

;53 岁的福特全职员工罗伯特·墨菲 (Robert Murphy) 表示，他对一些工人的工资只有从事类似工作的其他工人的一半感到不安。他还指责福特没有提高效率，减少浪费，以找到资金来提高工资。

;

;该工厂生产高调的 Ranger 和 Bronco 卡车，但它从较为普通的福克斯转向。墨菲说，在过渡期间，数百个备用变速箱和其他零件被取出并销毁在工厂后面，这是该公司可以避免的成本。福特没有立即回应对传输发表评论的请求。

;

;“这里百分之九十九点九的人希望成​​为优秀工作场所的一部分，”墨菲说。

;

;此次罢工雄心勃勃，旨在挑战;三个汽车制造商立即;，但具有战略意义，因为保持大多数工厂运转可以保留工人的罢工资金。

;

;如果无法达成协议，Fain 并不排除采取更激烈的行动，例如全公司范围内的罢工。

;

;自午夜罢工开始以来，该工厂已被洪水淹没。不久之后，一位工厂工人的支持者、一位不愿透露姓名的 38 岁通用汽车老员工表示，他认为在汽车制造商屈服于工会要求之前，罢工行动不会停止。

;

;“我们我们应得的，”他说。

;

;9月8日，摩洛哥高阿特拉斯山脉发生毁灭性地震，地震发生地的贫困地区居民纷纷寻求帮助向国家及其领导者穆罕默德六世国王致敬。

;

;然而，这位拥有巨大权力的君主一直保持低调，此后仅露面过三次。他在拉巴特主持了两次与官员举行的紧急响应会议，并参观了灾区附近马拉喀什的一家医院，在全国范围内呼吁捐献者后，他在那里献血了。

;

;国王通常与国王保持着王室距离。公众并远离政治纷争，尚未访问受影响最严重的地区，那里发生了 6.8 级地震，造成 2,900 多人死亡，这是自 1960 年以来摩洛哥死亡人数最多的一次。

;

;这种回避公众关注的做法一直是这是他自 1999 年 35 岁继承父亲王位以来的统治标志，当时他掌管了一个贫穷、经济停滞、政治受压制的北非王国。

;

;他对异议的态度比他的父亲更加温和。父亲哈桑二世推行经济改革，吸引了外国投资者并扩大了工业基础，使王国成为非洲的经济强国。

;

;但国王的头衔包括皇家最高指挥官武装部队和忠诚的指挥官，一直对政治变革持谨慎态度，几乎没有产生任何权力，批评者称，即使在危机中，这也会扼杀政府的主动性。

;

;“当国王不在场时，不仅法国美国地中海学院教授阿布巴克尔·贾迈 (Aboubakr Jamai) 表示：“政府无法发挥作用，但当遇到重大危机时，国家也无法发挥作用。”

;

;一位政府消息人士称，摩洛哥有机构和民事机构该官员因无权接受媒体采访而要求不透露姓名，他还表示，当局已在地震造成的后勤困难。

;

;2011 年，突尼斯和埃及爆发大规模抗议活动，推翻了独裁统治者，支持民主的团体在摩洛哥各地集会，要求变革。穆罕默德将更多权力交给民选议会，但这只是有限的转变。

;

;国王保留从席位最多的政党中选择总理、否决内阁任命和提名非民选官员的权利关键部门。

;

;温和的伊斯兰 PJD 政党在 2011 年之后获得支持，但发现其权力被削弱。

;

;分析人士和权利团体表示，政治阶层在很大程度上已被拉拢，而真正的权力掌握在国王和他的“Makhzen”，即摩洛哥旧的政治机构手中。他们说许多批评者已经离开摩洛哥或被监禁。

;

;与此同时，摩洛哥媒体避免对敏感话题进行批评性报道，例如国王宣布的任何决定。

;

;政府发言人可以无法联系到您对本文发表评论。但政府表示，审判不是政治性的，而是司法部门的事。它还说摩洛哥人都享有平等的政治自由。

;

;但地震却显示出摩洛哥经济发展的不平衡。北部的丹吉尔和卡萨布兰卡有高速列车连接，但在更南部的地震区，山路必须通过 ;驴;为因地震而与外界隔绝的贫困偏远村庄运送物资。

;

;一些在阿马齐格或柏柏尔村庄抱怨边缘化和;孤立;。

;

;政府表示正在努力增加投资，促进较贫困和偏远地区的可持续发展，并且不存在歧视政策。

;

;同时，福布斯2015年排名之王跻身非洲首富之列，个人财富价值超过 50 亿美元。自登基以来，皇家控股公司阿尔马达扩大了投资，其中包括在摩洛哥和整个非洲的采矿、银行、零售、可再生能源和电信企业的股份。

;

;国王命令阿尔马达捐款向地震应对基金提供 10 亿迪拉姆（1 亿美元）。

;

;穆罕默德在位期间公开露面变得越来越少，主要限于少数年度仪式活动。他经常出国进行私人旅行，包括前往摩洛哥前殖民统治者法国。他已经多年没有接受媒体采访了。

;

;虽然国王自地震以来很少露面，但政府官员也一直保持低调。

;

;政府发言人刚刚发表了讲话有一次露面，宣读了一份关于受害者基金的声明，没有回答任何问题。这促使一些评论员表示，这场危机要求部长们提高公众知名度。

;

;“负责卫生、住房、设备、水和食品的相关部门的部长应该站出来，”El Manar Esslimi 说，知名大学教授和媒体经常评论员，其言论通常支持建制派，他在社交媒体网站 X 上发帖写道。

;

;“有必要进行逐步转型，以保证西班牙足球的未来，”它说。

;

;“有必要进行逐步转型，以保证西班牙足球的未来。” >;

;西班牙上个月赢得世界杯后，卢比亚莱斯据称在悉尼主动亲吻球员珍妮·埃尔莫索的嘴唇，此举引起了轩然大波，最初由 81 名球员组成的组织发起了抵制活动。

;

;该 39 人组织在声明中表示：“对 RFEF 的具体修改是基于对那些在 RFEF 工作中煽动、隐瞒或赞扬侵犯妇女尊严的态度的人采取零容忍态度。”

;

;“到目前为止发生的变化还不足以让球员感到安全。”

;

;西班牙足联发言人表示，足协正在与球员进行谈判，并推迟了最近举行的新闻发布会——任命的教练蒙特塞·托梅将于 9 月 22 日宣布西班牙在国家联赛中对阵瑞典的比赛阵容。

;

;这场比赛将决定哪些欧洲国家有资格参加 2024 年巴黎奥运会。

;

;

;如果实施新法律，他们可能面临高达 30,000 欧元（31,965 美元）的罚款，并暂停其联合会执照 2 至 15 年。

;

;他;周五出庭;向法官作证，法官正在调查这一吻以及随后涉嫌的行为是否强迫埃尔莫索说这是“一种相互的姿态”，构成性虐待和胁迫。

;

;埃尔莫索在对鲁维亚莱斯的投诉中表示，他和他的随行人员在未经她批准的情况下发表了一份声明，引用了她所说的吻话这是一种“相互的、完全自发的姿态”。

;近十年来，为了打击性别歧视并实现与男队的平等，女队一直与 RFEF 在比赛条件问题上发生争执。

;

;鲁比亚莱斯去年被世界足球管理机构国际足联停职后，西班牙足联成立了新董事会周;解雇了豪尔赫·维尔达;，他世界杯期间执教球队，并由助手托梅取代了他。

;;US President Joe Biden said on Friday that no one wants the United Auto Workers (UAW) union to strike in its labor dispute with the big three US automakers, but workers should see a share of the "record profits" those companies are making.;
;;
;;US President Joe Biden delivers remarks on his economic agenda at Prince George's Community College in Largo, Maryland, US September 14, 2023. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst/File photo;
;

;US President Joe Biden on Friday said "no one wants a strike" but that car companies have enjoyed record profits in recent years without sharing them fairly with workers, hours after the United Auto Workers began strikes at Detroit's three biggest automakers.

;

;The UAW strike at three factories owned by General Motors, Ford and Chrysler-owner Stellantis on Friday, kicked off the most ambitious US industrial ;labor action; in decades.

;

;Biden said "record corporate profits" should lead to "record contracts" for the UAW, but that the profits have not been shared fairly with workers.

;

;"No one wants a strike, but I respect workers' right to use their options under the collective bargaining" system, Biden said. "I understand their frustration."

;

;So far in the strike negotiations, "the companies have made some significant offers," Biden said. "But I believe they should go further to ensure record corporate profits mean record contracts for the UAW."

;

;Biden said he has been in touch with both sides in the negotiations, and will dispatch two members of his team, Gene Sperling and Labor Secretary Julie Su, to Detroit to ensure the administration's involvement in the talks and a "win-win agreement."

;

;Biden, who predicted over the ;Labor Day weekend; that the union would not strike, spoke to union and automaker leaders on Thursday.

;

;The Biden administration is also ;discussing emergency aid; to protect smaller firms that supply US auto manufacturers, a source with knowledge of the matter said on Thursday.

;

;During a summer of labor unrest, Biden has ;touted; his pro-labor policies by speaking out for unions, while his administration behind the scenes has tried to smooth the way for deals with employers to avoid costly walkouts, union leaders and administration officials said.

;

;But in a reminder of how hard it is to appease energized workers while tamping down on price hikes that cause inflation, Biden and ;auto workers' union UAW; - the only major union not to endorse his 2024 presidential run - are not on the same page.

;

;Labor unions like the UAW - which represents 146,000 workers - are key to Biden's game plan for winning reelection in 2024. He needs their support to win key states like Pennsylvania and Michigan again, which stand to bear the brunt of any ;major strikes against carmakers;.

;

;Biden, 80, is tying his 2024 re-election bid to the health of the economy, highlighting job growth, rising wages and fading recession fears and a prolonged strike could threaten that.

; Sat, 16 Sep 2023 02:55:04 +0800 Amini death anniversary sees heavy security in Iran - rights groups, witnesseshttps://reuters.com/article/iran-women/amini-death-anniversary-sees-heavy-security-in-iran-rights-groups-witnesses-idUSKBN30L0JZ

;

;Iranian security forces deployed in the hometown of Mahsa Amini in anticipation of a flare-up in unrest marking this weekend's first anniversary of her death in morality police custody, witnesses, social media posts and rights groups said on Friday.

;

;The death on Sept. 16 of Amini, a 22-year-old Kurd arrested for allegedly flouting the Islamic Republic's mandatory dress code, sparked months of anti-government protests that spiralled into the biggest show of opposition to the authorities in years.

;

;Many, with ;women and young people; often at the forefront, called for an end to more than four decades of Shi'ite clerical rule. Over 500 people including 71 minors were killed in the protests, hundreds injured and thousands arrested in unrest that was eventually crushed by security forces, rights groups said.

;

;In Amini's birthplace in Iran's western province of Kurdistan, a rights activist said there was a "heavy presence of security forces".

;

;Another activist said a small gathering of protesters chanted anti-government slogans before quickly dispersing.

;

;The activists spoke on condition of anonymity, citing a fear of government reprisals amid a growing clampdown on dissent as the anniversary approached.

;

;Social media posts spoke of security force deployments in several cities, mainly within Kurdistan. The reports could not be immediately verified.

;

;In a statement, the Norway-based human rights group Hengaw said several Kurdish cities in western Iran “have experienced an atmosphere of intimidation and the declaration of a state of war in recent days”. It said numerous citizens had been detained.

;

;Hengaw added that military personnel were positioned on top of Tapeh Qawkh, a hill overlooking Saqez, while residents had witnessed a surge in helicopter activity over the city.

;

;Social media posts quoted Saqez residents as saying that authorities had installed new surveillance cameras around the city, apparently to monitor and identify protesters.

;

;Reuters could not verify any of these accounts.

;

;On Friday, web monitor Netblocks reported "significant disruption to internet connectivity in the (southeastern city of) Zahedan ... targeting anti-government protests ... on the eve of the anniversary of Mahsa Amini's death".

;

;Social media postings said weekly protests were held in Zahedan on Friday with slogans including "Death or freedom".

;

;Authorities have accused the United States and Israel and their local agents of fomenting the unrest to destabilise Iran.

;

;In a statement on Friday, US President Joe Biden said: "Mahsa's story did not end with her brutal death. She inspired a historic movement — Woman, Life, Freedom — that has impacted Iran and influenced people across the globe."

;

;"We reaffirm our commitment to the courageous people of Iran ... And together with our allies and partners, we stand with them," Biden added.

;

;Without naming Biden, Iran's Foreign Ministry spokesperson Nasser Kanaani rejected as "double standards and lies" Western expressions of support for women's rights in Iran. His posting on the X platform was accompanied by videos apparently showing mistreatment of women by Western and Israeli police.

;

;Britain on Friday ;imposed sanctions; on four Iranian officials and the ;United States said it was sanctioning; more than two dozen individuals and entities connected to Iran's "violent suppression" of protests.

;

;In a report last month, Amnesty International said Iranian authorities "have been subjecting victims' families to arbitrary arrest and detention, imposing cruel restrictions on peaceful gatherings at grave sites, and destroying victims' gravestones".

;

;Security forces ;detained; Amini's uncle Safa Aeli on Sept. 5, relatives told Reuters.

;

;Many journalists, lawyers, activists, students, academics, artists, public figures and members of ethnic minorities accused of links with the protest wave, as well as relatives of protesters killed in the unrest, have been arrested, summoned, threatened or fired from jobs in the past few weeks, according to Iranian and Western human rights groups.

;

;Iran's Etemad daily reported in August that the lawyer for Amini's family also faced charges of "propaganda against the system". If convicted, Saleh Nikbakht faces a jail sentence of between one and three years.

REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz/File Photo;
;

;The Texas Senate began deliberations in the impeachment trial of Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton on Friday following eight days of testimony from whistle blowers alleging corruption and defenders saying he did nothing wrong.

;

;Paxton, a conservative Republican firebrand who is strongly aligned with former US President Donald Trump, returned to the Senate chamber on Friday for the first time since the trial opened on Sept. 5. He faces 16 articles of impeachment in the trial, in which the Republican-dominated Texas Senate serves as the jury.

;

;Paxton has called the trial a political witch hunt.

;

;Paxton, who has been suspended from office pending the outcome of the trial, faces permanent ouster if at least two-thirds of the Texas Senate -- which includes 19 Republicans, among them his wife, who is not allowed to vote, and 12 Democrats -- agree to convict on any count. It is the first impeachment proceeding against a statewide office holder in Texas in over a century.

;

;"We discovered unprecedented abuse in the Texas attorney general's office by Mr. Paxton," said Republican state Representative Andrew Murr, who opened the prosecution's closing arguments. "As the state's top cop, his conduct is and was inexcusable."

;

;Murr urged senators not to leave Paxton in office.

;

;"He's betrayed us and the people of Texas," Murr said. "If he's given the opportunity, he will continue to abuse the power given to him."

;

;In Paxton's defense, lawyer Tony Buzbee ridiculed prosecution witnesses, dismissed evidence as "supposition and guesses and mights and maybes," and said that the trial was being carried out purely for political reasons.

;

;"There is shame here. And the shame sits right there, that they would bring this case in this chamber with no evidence," he said. "I am proud to represent Attorney General Ken Paxton. If this can happen to him, it can happen to anyone."

;

;Following the closing arguments, senators began deliberating in private, and they can take as long as they wish. Their votes will be made public following their closed-door meeting, which will continue over the weekend if no decisions are made on Friday.

;

;Paxton is accused by several former top aides of corruption and abuse of power, mostly in relation to official actions allegedly carried out to protect a wealthy political donor who was under a federal investigation and to cover up an extramarital affair.

;

;The trial has exposed rifts in the Texas Republican Party between the social conservatives, who have held sway for the past decade and back Paxton, and the traditional conservatives, who say his actions have brought shame on the party and the state. Paxton was ;overwhelmingly impeached; by the Republican-dominated Texas House in May.

;

;Paxton, who faces a separate state securities fraud trial and is also under investigation by the FBI, has been dogged by corruption allegations since his first election in 2014. Still, he easily defeated traditional conservative candidate George P. Bush in a primary then Democrat Rochelle Garza in his re-election bid in November.

;

;Paxton's legal team has painted the former top aides who accused him of corruption as mutinous political centrists. The prosecution put a parade of the aides who became whistle blowers on the stand, each of whom detailed their conservative bona fides before testifying about what they witnessed in the attorney general's office that led them to take their accusations to the FBI in 2020.

;

;Paxton's lawyers countered with current state officials who testified that the activities that raised suspicions among the whistle blowers were within his powers as attorney general.

;

;As attorney general, Paxton backed powerful oil and gas interests and pursued restrictions on ;abortion; and ;transgender rights;. He has led Republican state opposition to the policies of Democratic presidents, and filed an unsuccessful lawsuit seeking to overturn Trump's 2020 election defeat.

;

;Paxton's impeachment was triggered by his request that House lawmakers approve a $3.3 million settlement he reached with former staff members who were fired after accusing him of abuse of office. State lawmakers did not fund the settlement.
